B000000W5B|4.0|GHS was the last recording the Stones made with Jimmy Miller, who had produced 4 previous Stones classics in a row. This one is posssibly the weakest under his stewardship, in that there's less consistency in the songs. 'The opener 'Dancing with Mr. D' is pretty good and features the Stones in a sleazy mood, with a solid guitar riff underpinning the whole song. Jagger's vocals lends a real menacing air to the whole track.<br /><br />Other highlights are 'Coming down again', an excellent ballad with Keith doing the vocals in a genuine melancholy fashion. 'Angie' the single taken from GHS is one of the Stones most famous ballads, and hasn't diminished over time at all. 'Winter is another fine Stones ballad, and Mick Taylor plays some excellent lead guitar here, and indeed his guitar work is well represented throughout the whole album.<br /><br />The other rockers 'Silver Train', 'Doo, doo, doo..' and '100 years ago' were more mediocre by the Stones past standards. But there is one other notable rocker other than the opener, and that is the closer, 'Star, star'. That number provides a rousing finale, using a typical Stones 'Chuck Berry' riff, and at the time of its release (1973) its lyrics caused the album to attract a certain amount of controversy, so nothing new there regarding the Stones.<br /><br />There is one other strange ballad, 'Can you hear the music'. It has a rather haunting sound to it, and although it's repetitive that tended to emphasise the point that the Stones were questioning whether this might be their last 'good' album. That seemed to prove the case with future releases which showed the Stones in gradual, yet definite musical decline (IMO).<br /><br />So if you are not a Stones fan generally, listen to this a few times first before making your mind up, as many of the tracks, especially the ballads grow on you.

B00000JBFW|5.0|It was during the hype of this reunion album that I got into Deep Purple. I watched the video for Perfect Strangers and I knew I just had to hear that song and have it permanently embedded in my brain. From the mountain-shattering organ at the beginning to the thundering classical structure at the end this song is heavy and haunting with Gillan singing like no one else could. I love his vocals on the title track and decided I had to find whatever I could with him singing.  <br /> <br />Looking back, I feel Gillan's voice tends to get a little whiny sounding at times and because of that I cannot get as thrilled about Wasted Sunsets as some other reviewers. But the aspects of his voice that I love are on the title track and most other songs on the album. I especially love the deep scream after the solo on Under the Gun, something he did well on Black Sabbath's Born Again. For the most part, the album introduces the 1980s generation of hard rock and metal fans to the monsterous sound of Deep Purple, combining both the thunder of the past and a new modern sound for 1984. When other bands were busy playing with synthesizers, Deep Purple brought back the hammond organ. Sadly, the following album explored a more commercial sound that didn't have the same grab-you-by-the-balls-and-throw-you-through-a-brick-wall kind of feel to it. This album stands alone in rock history. Treasure it for all it's worth.
038572179X|5.0|Ian McEwan incorporates an explicit and descriptive style of writing that is characteristic of his novels.  His language is rich and lush, and he utilizes his mastery of the English language to its fullest extent; the vocabulary is evocative, effective and sometimes menacing in describing every intricately framed detail.  <br /> <br />The story unfolds rather lazily, the plot moving through the viewpoints of the different characters. This gives the reader a chance to explore the personalities of the different characters. This languid style of writing also creates a connection with the initial setting of the book- a sultry and sluggish summer day in the year 1935. The protagonist of the book is a thirteen year old named Briony Tallis, who is in the midst of writing a play to be enacted by herself and her cousins. The self-composed play is in honor of the arrival of the Tallis' oldest son, Leon, who arrives with his friend. McEwan describes an innocuous and rather drab situation such as this with rich detail, which makes one wonder if there is actually a reason for intricacy.  <br /> <br />However, the plotline unravels slightly when the narration switches. The world is now seen through the eyes of Cecilia Tallis, Briony's older sister. Cecilia is hassled by the new developments in her relationship to Robbie Turner, the cleaning lady's son and her childhood friend. The two of them, in a fleeting moment of undeniable passion, cross the boundary from friends to lovers. Briony accidentally witnesses the act of consummation and, rudely awakened from her insularity, cannot comprehend the level of anger rising within her. She believes her beloved friend Robbie to have turned into a \\"maniac\\" in order to have engaged in such a sordid act with her sister. The anger then turns into contempt, both towards her sister and Robbie. This sequence of events is the pivotal point in the novel, the reason for the shattering of personalities for which atonement is necessary. Briony destroys the newly blossomed love between Robbie and Cecilia because of her virulent disdain for them by telling a horrible lie. This lie then haunts her for years to come and decides the fate of the lovers. <br /> <br />After the happenings of the fateful day are wrapped up, the reader is transported five years hence. McEwan's writing style is transformed into an absolute state of macabre. His initially sluggish prose is abandoned as he transforms the Tallis family into a household full of distrust, brought about as a result of a peculiar combination of disgust, malice and love. He makes full use of the morbidity of the English language in his depiction of the Tallis family and of the state of the world during the Second World War. We find that Robbie and Cecilia's love has withstood time and the war barely scars it. Cecilia has disowned her family and has cut off all contact with Briony. Briony takes up a vocation in nursing, tending to wounded soldiers day in and day out. She attempts at reconciliation with Cecilia, now having realized the shamefulness of her act. The readers growing annoyance with Briony's meddlesome behaviour is now transformed into that of sympathy- she has after all, acquired some sense of self-awareness and grown up.  <br /> <br />In the conclusion, McEwan offers a bizarre and bittersweet twist to a supposedly coming of age story. The play that is written in the summer of 1935, is re-performed at Briony's seventy-seventh birthday, who has now become a published novelist. In spite of her success, Briony ponders about the atonement of her treacherous crime. She asks herself \\"How can a novelist achieve atonement when, with her absolute power of deciding outcomes, she is also God?\\"(Pg 372). The realization comes to her that the crime she committed can be atoned in her stories, but however cannot be atoned in reality. This brings out the veracity of the tale; in no real life situation is any crime, lie, or deceiving act brought to complete justice, andthe power of absolution is a far-fetched possibility to the people on the receiving end of an incorrect judgment. <br /> <br />A brilliantly constructed story, with enthralling characters and resounding themes of love, war, betrayal and absolution, Atonement serves as McEwan's masterpiece.

0684803356|1.0|I normally don't put a book down without finishing it, especially one in the genre of classic American literature.  However, Hemingway's English translations were so irritating, trite, and immature that I could not get past them.  The use of \\"thy\\" and \\"thou\\" to indicate the ud. form is ridiculous in 20th century English.  Quoting the characters as asking, \\"How do you call yourself?\\" instead of \\"What is your name?\\" is downright silly.  If Hemingway really wanted to convey what the characters were saying literally, he should have simply quoted them in Spanish and provided a translation in parentheses or in an index.  Regardless, who needs a literal translation?  How is \\"How do you call yourself\\" better than \\"What is your name\\"?  And is it really important to know who uses ud. to whom when this form doesn't even exist in modern English?  I found these \\"translations\\" so distracting from what was going on that I couldn't continue past chapter 2.  I get the impression that the hundreds of reviewers who have raved about this book over the past 65 years don't speak Spanish.

B000002JSP|4.0|THE BAND: Robert Plant (vocals), Jimmy Page (guitars), John Paul Jones (bass, piano, synth & keyboards), John Bonham (drums & percussion).<br /><br />THE DISC: (1979) 7 songs clocking in at approximately 43 minutes. The digitally remastered version released in 1994. Included with the disc is a 3-page foldout containing song titles/credits and all original album artwork. Robert Plant is credited on all 7 songs, Jimmy Page on 5, and (perhaps) surprisingly John Paul Jones on 6. This is Led Zeppelin's 8th and final studio album. Recorded at Polar Music Studio in Stockholm, Sweden. Label - Swan Song / Atlantic.<br /><br />COMMENTS: If I had to stack all of Led Zeppelin's albums together, this would end op being my least favorite Zeppelin album. Not to say that it's bad (which it definitely is NOT)... but it's simply not in that 'classic' category that ALL the other Zeppelin albums are in. In fact, if there's one disposable Zeppelin album, this is it. Dare to compare it to Led Zeppelin's \\"1-4\\", \\"Houses Of The Holy\\", \\"Physical Graffiti\\", or \\"Presence\\"... well, \\"In Through The Out Door\\" falls easily to the bottom of the list. Anyone who doesn't rank this album last (or close to it) is kidding themselves. This album has a totally different feel to it... almost 'commercial'. The hits - \\"Fool In The Rain\\", \\"In The Evening\\" and \\"All My Love\\" are downright pleasant. All good songs, but none of them crunch and shred like we know the ultimate guitar God can. You'll also notice that 6 of the 7 songs are co-authored by John Paul Jones - thus, extremely heavy on the keyboards/synthesizers. Page's guitar takes a back seat on several songs here. Authorized books on the band have mentioned Jimmy Page being so incapacitated due to his heroin addiction, that John Paul Jones actually stepped up during this time and and did most of the writing with Plant. \\"South Bound Saurez\\", and the ten-and-a-half minute \\"Carouselambra\\" are ultimately forgettable. \\"Hot Dog\\" belongs on a country & western album somewhere. The final cut, \\"I'm Gonna Crawl\\", is one of their weaker attempts at a rich library of blues tunes they've covered over the years. John Bonham died within months of this release. As far as the album cover is concerned - I've always wondered if there was a significance to it. This is a good rock album... simply not on par with anything the band had done to this point (3.5 stars).The final cut, \\"I'm Gonna Crawl\\", is one of their weaker attempts at a rich library of blues tunes they've covered over the years. John Bonham died within months of this release. As far as the album cover is concerned - I've always wondered if there was a significance to it. This is a good rock album... simply not on par with anything the band had done to this point (3.5 stars).
B000002U9Y|4.0|Rating: 4.25 Stars<br /><br />I find it quite amusing when the word \\"uneven\\" is used to describe \\"A Saucerful Of Secrets\\" seeing that Syd Barrett's influence is still quite strong on this Pink Floyd effort.  That word takes on a new (and deeper) meaning when used in conjunction with anything associated with Syd.  Yet, \\"uneven\\" is an accurate assessment in that this release contains three classic Floydian adventures (\\"Let There Be More Light\\", \\"Set The Controls For The Heart Of The Sun\\", and \\"A Saucerful Of Secrets'), one beautifully mellow Rick Wright composition (\\"Remember A Day\\"), and three real oddities (\\"Corporal Clegg\\", \\"See Saw\\", and \\"Jugband Blues\\") penned by Waters, Wright, and Barrett respectively.  To give you an idea of the nature of these three oddities, suffice it to say that they would have fit right in on Floyd's preceding album, \\"The Piper At The Gates Of Dawn\\".<br /><br />The first three cuts; \\"Let There Be More Light\\", \\"Remember A Day\\", and \\"Set The Controls For The Heart Of The Sun\\", are excellent and set an exceptional mood that is unfortunately broken by the fourth cut, \\"Corporal Clegg\\".  The first grouping of three consists of sonic abstractions loaded with plenty of keyboard, guitar, and percussion set in perfect counterpoint to Roger Water's steady bass lines.  \\"Corporal Clegg\\" is stark and bare in comparison, substituting instead heaviness and, eventually, frivolity in place of the mind-bending excursions found in the first three compositions.  Taken by itself, \\"Corporal Clegg\\" is a very good tune but I have always had a difficult time fully appreciating it in its position as the fourth cut on \\"A Saucerful Of Secrets\\" after such a stellar beginning.  Fortunately, the title cut re-establishes the mood set by the first three songs and is quite a psychedelic adventure in and of itself.  \\"See Saw\\" continues the adventure on a far less serious note taking the listener to a fairy tale playground and somewhat preparing them for the closing gem, \\"Jugband Blues\\", penned by the Crazy Diamond himself.<br /><br />Far more than simply a transitional album, \\"A Saucerful Of Secrets\\" profiles a maturing band that is still performing on the edge of lunacy while transitioning onto a more focused and purposeful musical path.  As it is with all of their pre-\\"Dark Side Of The Moon\\" releases, I cautiously recommend \\"A Saucerful Of Secrets\\" to those who are only familiar with the \\"rock radio\\" edits from this fine band.  If you had trouble relating to the albums that those radio-friendly edits came from, then this one is probably not for you.  However, if you think that you are up to the challenge, this album may very well expand your musical horizon beyond anything you might have hoped for and, consequently, send you off on a mission to experience other early Pink Floyd offerings as well.em, \\"Jugband Blues\\", penned by the Crazy Diamond himself. <br /> <br />Far more than simply a transitional album, \\"A Saucerful Of Secrets\\" profiles a maturing band that is still performing on the edge of lunacy while transitioning onto a more focused and purposeful musical path.   As it is with all of their pre-\\"Dark Side Of The Moon\\" releases, I cautiously recommend \\"A Saucerful Of Secrets\\" to those who are only familiar with the \\"rock radio\\" edits from this fine band.   If you had trouble relating to the albums that those radio-friendly edits came from, then this one is probably not for you.  However, if you think that you are up to the challenge, this album may very well expand your musical horizon beyond anything you might have hoped for and, consequently, send you off on a mission to experience other early Pink Floyd offerings as well.  <br />
0060005696|5.0|This book is one of the most interesting books I have ever read. The basic premise of this book is that the more choice we have, the more anxious we become about the decisions we have to make. Think for example, about how many different stores there are in a mall. You want to buy a dress shirt, but which store do you go into? Will the Gap have a better deal than Banana Republic? Or maybe Macy's or Lord & Taylor will have a better shirt. But then, which shirt do you pick once you decide what store to walk into? All these decisions prove to be quite exhausting, despite our unconscience ability to make such them on a constant basis. <br /> <br />Don't believe me cause Im just another dude? Well, it was required reading in my psychology class on personal security at The Ohio State University. Had a great professor...this book changed how I make decisions in everyday life.

B00001OH7P|5.0|I LOVE this album and think its both Bowie's best and essential to any record collection. <br /> <br />Sparing you the track-by-track run down, I just want to add my two favorite parts of this classic disc: <br /> <br />1) \\"Five Years\\"   <br />This track is NEVER played on the radio but is so absolutely masterful it will blow your mind.  The entire song is one long creschendo, and at its climax is the most soul-sucking, gut-wrenching rock-and-roll scream ever recorded.  The lyrics - about reactions to the announcement that the world will come to an end in five years - are incredibly original and evocative (\\"My brain hurt like a warehouse it had no room to spare.  I had to cram so many things to store everything in there.\\", \\"I thought I saw you in an ice cream parlor drinking milkshakes cold and long.\\", \\"The newsguy wept and told us, earth was really dying.  He cried so much his face was wet.  Then I knew he was not lying\\".  Put this track on repeat and drink it in. <br /> <br />2. The *transition* between \\"Soul Love\\" and \\"Moonage Daydream\\". <br />Afficianados of this album know that on the back of the album cover are the famous words \\"TO BE PLAYED AT MAXIMUM VOLUME\\".  A cool rock-and-roll packaging trick to be sure, HOWEVER - I've not seen anyone write about one of the REASONS behind this directive. <br />\\"Soul Love\\" is a very slow-tempo, meandering and relatively mellow track which, as it progresses, lulls you into a kind of a trance.  The pacing is very steady, and toward the end of the song you can tell that it will end in a very long fade-out, and you expect this to happen along with the usual silence between tracks.   INSTEAD, what you are treated to is the THURDEROUS opening riff of \\"Moonage Daydream\\" - probably the loudest sound on the entire album!!!  That monster riff and the immortal words \\"I'M AN ALLIGATOR, I'M A MOMMA-PAPPA COMING FOR YOU!\\" - when played at MAXIMUM VOLUME - will surprise and scare the living ---- out of you!  THAT is why the album coverexhorts you to play it at maximum volume!

B000002U9W|5.0|On the passing of Pink Floyd co-founder Syd Barrett, I noticed quite a bit of celebration of Barrett's work.  I had not paid attention to him before, so I listened to some of the clips here on Amazon of Barrett's best.   <br /> <br />Folks: Atom Heart Mother is real music, and much better music than anything I heard from the late Mr. Barrett's selections.  I say this not to speak ill of Mr. Barrett, but to encourage serious music enthusiasts to give The Cow Album renewed consideration. <br /> <br />The title track of Atom Heart Mother is a suite of rock and symphonic-influenced mini-compositions expertly performed and woven.  The \\"Funky Dung\\" interlude delivers some of the clearest most precise blues-rock you'll ever hear. <br /> <br />Did you like \\"Shine On You Crazy Diamond\\" (the long version)? <br />Did you like Days of Future Passed (Moody Blues)? <br />Then sit back, with good quality headphones, and explore Atom Heart Mother.   <br /> <br />Parts you'll like, parts might annoy you, but this is music to study and think about.  Spotlight in your mind the horns, the voice work, the bass lines, the drums, the sound effects. See which parts work best for you.   <br /> <br />I wore out my first copy, in vinyl, doing just that back in 1972 :-)  <br /> <br />P.S.:  Don't judge the album by the 30 second clips here on Amazon -- they just don't give it justice and a couple of them end up sampling portions of the songs that are quiet sound effects.  You have to hear the album itself.

What a waste...when you have honest acting talent like Neeson, USE IT!  And Christian Bale did a good job with what he'd been given, however, I've never seen a Bruce Wayne who was as clueless and stupid as the one this movie delivered.  (His on-screen flame, a character played by Katie Holmes, seemed to have more common sense).  The best performances really came from Gary Oldman (who, I'm convinced, couldn't turn in a bad performance in any movie) and Cillian Murphy (unfortunately, his character was given -what?- maybe five minutes of actual screen time). <br /> <br />Don't get me wrong: it is nice to see a Batman who isn't surrounded by ice-skating snowmen/burglars or spinning neon lights (as in the horrible Joel Shumacher outings).  But really...a sonic machine that attacks the town's water supply?  A group of secret assassin ninja spies who want nothing more than to leave Gotham City in ruins?  Although almost everything was there: all the elements to make a really good, really dark movie for the Dark Knight, it's the \\"almost\\" that leaves me wishing I had seen a better film.  It only needed a strong story (with a blelievable, credible threat for Batman to face) to carry it all through, and sadly, that's the one thing the movie didn't have.
0440234743|4.0|Once again it is another good read by Grisham. It is hard to think what my will would be like if I get over a million dollars. I cannot see leaving it to a woman in some remote southn american jungle.
0618477942|5.0|I have been a fan of Dykes to Watch Out For, Bechdel's pitch-perfect and depthy comic strip about a group of lesbians and their friends, since high school about twelve years ago, and the arrival of a new work by Bechdel is always an event to be heralded by the same day purchase of her book and my holing up with chocolates to read it all the way through.<br /><br />This one was a little different than the Dykes series, though, because its complexity, both in the drawings and the writing, really deserved a slower-paced reading so I could ponder all of the literary connections she made, and the thoughts and actions that brought up so many interesting feelings and thoughts in me.<br /><br />Bechdel's Dad owned the local Funeral Home (the \\"Fun Home\\"), and restored their old home to museum-like glory, obsessively painting, rearranging, and disallowing the personal touches and tastes of his wife and kids in favor of period pieces of furniture and decoration.<br /><br />Between the Fun Home and the restoration, Alison starts to show us the stilted way in which her father is living and forcing them all to live. Why does he need to have such control over his surroundings?<br /><br />It is only when Bechdel is away at college that she discovers lesbianism and realizes that her differences have a name. When she comes out to her parents, she discovers the secret that her parents had been trying to keep under cover for years.<br /><br />Alson and her Dad are both voracious readers, and their stories are shown against a backdrop of classic and other books, which makes the experience of her autobiography (to this point) so much richer.<br /><br />This is a five star hit that I think deserves a lot of attention from people who aren't usually comic readers. The success of Persepolis and a few other mainstream graphic novels have paved the way for this to be a hit. I will certainly be recommending it to all of my book friends.

It is interesting to see how my son reacts to the original movies vs the new CAD/high tech episodes. I espically like some of the additional footage that was deleted from the theater versions.
B000002KD9|5.0|I must say, I agree with David Ludd, that the editorial review does not do this classic album justice, and Neil's phrase about 'mother nature on the run' is so obviously an ecology statement that it is bewildering how anyone claiming to be a reviewer could see it as a 'riddle'. <br /> <br />Neil's versatility is legendary, and the man who gave us one of the most beautiful love songs ever written, Harvest Moon, and the rock anthem Like A Hurricane, built an incredibily solid foundation with this timeless album. <br /> <br />While we all have our favorites, this is one of those rare albums where you could almost pick a track at random and it would be a classic. <br /> <br />To me, the man has never put out a bad album, but this is one that will ensure his musical immortality.
